Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
@Mylo I have the chain and the tool to place the data onto the chain, I would not worry too much about breaking the file up, you want yo do like what ffmpeg does when it encodes and stream the video directly to a file in disk. From there I will use c code to fread the the file into 8kb chunks of hex ( its actually a bit less than that) add a seq number then scan forward to the next chuck read it and send. I can probably get bandwidth though this chain of 400-500kb a second. Depending on CPU power, something like my ryzen 2700x might be even faster then that and I will test it don't worry ;)

The problem I have it getting that data out of the chain and putting it back together

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: But it might even be some reverse C code of the input, in the deamon itself that extracts the op return from every tx in a block as the block is received, we need to never use the wallet for this for obvious reasons.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: So your dapp will likely just be reading a file I think vlc can do this or at least it works for partial DL torrent files

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: The api to send will be a combo of RPC calls from market maker and komodod btw

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I could try to port all the TxBlast API into komodod itself ... but hat seems very dangerous thing to do ü§î

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, better not include a "nuke" in komodod

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can do what oracle does, but in reverse, put the previous txid in the opreturn also

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then given any 8000 bytes data, you can just get the prior transactions until you get to the start

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
you will need to buffer things anyway, so using the algo like:
set maxseqid by scanning the opreturn, save the 8kb in its spot fseek(fp,seqid * 8000,SEEK_SET), fwrite(...)
then when you have the first N chunks, start playback
you can validate the entire linked list by starting from maxseqid and iterating backward

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
@blackjok3r If you'll stream HLS data sequence shouldn't be a problem if you'll also generate manifest file (.m3u8) in which chunks playback sequence declared.
So for a life streaming it should be a mediaserver on one side  which generating HLS output from input (stream on input or screen capture) - let's say 10 chunks (1.ts, 2.ts and so on, each chunk is 10 seconds by HLS standart recommendations) + manifest where declared playback sequency:
```
1.ts
2.ts
...
10.ts```
Then you have to continue publish chunks to oracle and refreshed manifest (with same name) depends of time elapsed. Let's say on next publishing it will be 
```
5.ts
6.ts
....
15.ts```
This manifest should be available by link/path for VLC like a http://sever/manifest.m3u8 
You can adjust video bitrate to match needed blockchain capacity

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: So you even shouldn't care about sequence downloading if you'll encode chunk file name

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
I dont think we can even use oracle to send the data... I have a tool based on TxBlaster API, which will read a file and seek though it taking 8KB at a time then sending. For the very first test I was using a huge hex string hardcoded inot marketmaker, and just sending the same data every time, I tried to randomly generate it but ran into pointer issues with C strings and gave up. 

We will then need a function or RPC in komodod for ac_streamer=1 chains that gathers this data and writes it out to a file i the same order it was sent, as it wont always arrive in order exactly, james suggeston of having the sequence number, then the previous txid, then fill the rest of the op_return with what fits, seems like a good ideo.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: @blackjok3r sure!  I‚Äôd still want some non-file access (rpc), browsers don‚Äôt have access to filesystem (sandbox) so need to chunkify anyway.  Unless streamed into rpc.  Chunkify is done but time-based in streaming, and playback already handled.  So as long as say (500kB) can be sent to an rpc, it‚Äôll work from browser too.  Limitations are sandboxed environment.  PWAs (progressive web apps) have access to camera/contacts/cache so this rpc method required for mobile streaming.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I think we cna make it to take a giant hex in RPC, as long as it can be enough at once to keep the blaster saturated.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: blaster works on mempool size and keeps it within a range. but I guess thats not really required in this case, that is only to keep the chain at capacity

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: as long as the mempool isnt hundreds of MBs

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: then eveyrhting will break

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the txblaster has one place in the code where it looks for the hex string to add to the opreturn.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: right now it is hardcoded

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: by changing it to a function call

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can make that function provide the hex string

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the function can be whatever that function can do

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a ram based queue that was fed in via rpc

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a file that is growing on disk that it is scanning and automatically grabbing the latest and putting it into the ram based queue

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so I would implement a ram based queue of blaster hexstrings

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then the function just dequeues the next packet from the queue, of course if queue is empty, then the blaster just sleeps for a bit or returns error or whatever

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then you can have an rpc call that adds to the blaster queue

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this allows an app level to monitor a file, and call rpc to add to the blaster queue

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: or just sampling a webcam directly and sending hex strings to the blaster queue

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is my advice on how to do this to make it reliable and flexible

Author: Alright#0419
Content: If OP_RETURN can be pruned and a node continue to function as normal, can it be changed/faked and a node continue to function as normal?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: answer is no, yes?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you mean prune opreturn from the blockchain data?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: txindex=0 would do that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a pruned node

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Yes, I see that's it's possible to run a BTC node that prunes OP_RETURN data to save space

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it prunes all tx data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: though not for tx in your wallet...

Author: Alright#0419
Content: so OP_RETURN is hashed along with the rest of data in tx?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: changing it would effect the hash?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: my question is that if you can run a node that simple ignores OP_RETURNs, can you run a node that replaces OP_RETURNs with arbitrary data, broadcast these faked OP_RETURNs and have other node accept them as valid?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: I'm assuming the answer is no, but I'm just curious as to how you can ignore/delete OP_RETURNs locally and have a node continue to function as normal

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: txid is double sha256 of the serialized transaction

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which includes all vouts, including opreturn vouts

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless you get a hash collision, your fake opreturn is rejected as invalid txid, or just treated as a different transaction and double spending the same inputs

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: opreturns dont get into the utxo DB

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Cool that makes a lot of sense, thank you üòÉ
